skills.name: Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction
Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication
Identify that a problem needs to be solved using division
Carry out mental divisions when the answer leaves a remainder

explanations.A: The combined height of St. Helens and Ben Nevis is 8,368 + 1,344 = 9,712. Mount Fuji is taller by 12,388 - 9,712 = 2,676 m.
explanations.B: I think you've found the combined height of St Helens and Ben Nevis, but you haven't compared this to Mount Fuji.
explanations.C: I think you have forgotten to first find the combined height of St Helens and Ben Nevis.
explanations.D: I think you have made an error in your calculations. Check these carefully.

explanations.A: I think you have made an error in your calculations. Check these carefully.
explanations.B: The combined height of Mount Fuji and Ben Nevis is 12,388 + 1,344 = 13,732. This is taller than St Helens by 13,732 - 8,368 = 5,364 m.
explanations.C: I think you have found the difference between the heights of Fuji and Ben Nevis.
explanations.D: I think you have combined the heights of the wrong mountains.

explanations.A: I think you have added all the numbers. If some money was handed out, this would be taken away from the money in the till.
explanations.B: I think you subtracted and added the wrong numbers. If you are handing out the money it is leaving the till, so we have to take it away.
explanations.D: I think you found the difference between what was taken and what was handed out, but remember there was some money in the till to start with.

explanations.A: I think you have added all the numbers. If some money was handed out, this would be taken away from the money in the till.
explanations.C: I think you found the difference between what was taken and what was handed out, but remember there was some money in the till to start with.
explanations.D: I think you subtracted and added the wrong numbers. If you are handing out the money it is leaving the till, so we have to take it away.

explanations.A: If there are 66 apples they could be split into 6 groups of 11 with none left over.
explanations.B: If there are 30 apples they could be split into 6 groups of 5 with none left over.
explanations.C: If there are 35 apples they could be split into 6 groups of 5 with 5 left over.

explanations.A: 50 divided by 7 is 7 remainder 1, so this could be the number of apples.
explanations.B: If there are 35 apples they could be split into 7 groups of 5 with none left over.
explanations.C: If there are 21 apples they could be split into 7 groups of 3 with none left over.
explanations.D: If there are 13 apples they could be split into 7 groups of 1 with 6 left over.

explanations.A: Not quite. If we are finding a total we don't multiply, we add.
explanations.B: Problem 1 reads 'has 12 more'. This means that adding is needed to answer the question. Problem 2 reads 'has 12 times as many', which means that multiplication is used.
explanations.C: Not quite. If we are finding a total we don't multiply, we add.
explanations.D: Not quite. 12 times as many means we have to multiply by 12.

explanations.A: Almost. Try thinking about problem 2 with fewer students and fewer pieces of art. This will help you to see what operation you need to do.
explanations.C: Problem 1 is solved by multiplying because product means multiply. Problem 2 is also solved by multiplication as each person has 32 pieces of art, and as there are 17 people there are 17 lots of 32 pieces of art, or 17 x 32.
explanations.D: Not quite. Try thinking about problem 2 with fewer students and fewer pieces of art. This will help you to see what operation you need to do. Remember that product means x

explanations.A: Not quite. Think carefully about which operation you need to use. This calculation gives the cost of 84 tickets.
explanations.B: Not quite. Think carefully about which operation you need to use. This calculation gives the amount of money left after buying one ticket.
explanations.C: Think carefully about the order of your numbers. This calculation gives an answer less that 1.
explanations.D: Dividing the amount of money, by the cost per ticket will give the number of tickets. So we do 84 ÷ 7.

explanations.A: All 104 legs belong to cows which each have 4 legs. So to find out how many cows there are we divide the number of legs by 4. So we do 104 ÷ 4
explanations.B: Think carefully about the order of your numbers. This calculation gives an answer less that 1.
explanations.C: Not quite. Think carefully about which operation you need to use. This calculation gives the amount of legs if one cow was removed.
explanations.D: Not quite. Think carefully about which operation you need to use. This calculation gives the number of legs that 104 cows have.
